p.text: [Div 2 insrt Amendment 33: Gaz 160 of 21 December 1973 p 5504]
This Division applies to proceedings in the Court under the Part 5 of Chapter 4 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 (in this Division called the subject Act).
[r 4 am Amendment 98: Gaz 142 of 19 October 1979 p 5275 ; Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]

For the purposes of applying rules other than this Part to proceedings to which this Division applies, unless the context or subject matter otherwise indicates or requires, plaintiff means “prosecutor”.
[r 5 subst Amendment 152: Gaz 103 of 29 June 1984 p 3411 ; am Amendment 314: Gaz 93 of 22 August 1997 p 6530.]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 5A] r 5A Assignment of business

p.text: [r 5A rep Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [92], effective 15 August 2005]
In addition to the rules mentioned in rules 2 and 3, the following provisions of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 apply, so far as applicable, to proceedings to which this Division applies:
rule 4.10,
rules 6.15 and 6.16,
Part 19,
rule 34.1,
Part 36.
[r 6 subst Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [93], effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.6.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 r 6.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 19, Pt 36, r 34.1, r 4.10, rr 6.15, 6.16.
The rules specified in SCR r 6 may be summarised as follows:
UCPR r 4.10 relates to the filing of court documents.
UCPR rr 6.15 and 6.16 relate to the appointment of a return date for a summons commencing proceedings.
UCPR Pt 19 relates to amendment of documents.
UCPR r 34.1 relates to notices to produce at a hearing.
UCPR Pt 36 relates to, and sets out, the principal effects of a judgment or order of the court.
Where an information is defective at common law as not providing sufficient particularity it cannot be amended after the time for commencing prosecutions under the relevant legislation has expired.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 7] r 7 Commencement of proceedings

p.text: Proceedings for an offence under any Act which may be taken before the Court in its summary jurisdiction shall be commenced in the Court by summons claiming an order under section 246 of the subject Act in respect of the offence and claiming that the defendant be dealt with according to law for commission of the offence.
[r 7 am Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.7.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 s 16(2), s 246, s 250.

Section 246 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 permits a prosecutor to apply for an order for the appearance of a person, or the apprehension of an offender, who is liable to be dealt with summarily in relation to an offence with which they have been charged. At least in relation to lesser crimes, an order to appear on notice is appropriate: Lake v Dobson (1980) 5 Petty Sessions Review 2221 at 2223. The section sets out the formal requirements governing the content of such orders. Section 250 of the Act provides for the procedure where the accused person does not obey an order to appear. Failure to include the words “the defendant is to be dealt with according to law for the commission of the offence” in the summons is a formal defect and s 16(2) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 operates to preclude an objection being allowed for such a defect. The court may dispense with the requirement to amend the summons to include such words: Authorised Officer Ian Beer v D'Aquino [2006] NSWSC 996; BC200607675 at [7] per Bell J.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.7.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 s 246.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Div 2 of Pt 75.

Notwithstanding the terms of this rule care should be taken to ensure that there is no contrary provision in the particular legislation which creates the substantive offence. For example, s 56(4) of the Consumer Protection Act 1969 requires that proceedings for offences under that Act shall be commenced by information: John L Pty Ltd v A-G (NSW) (1987) 163 CLR 508; 73 ALR 545 . The failure to obtain and serve an order in accordance with s 246 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 and Div 2 of Pt 75 of the SCR at the time the summons is served is not a defect such as would justify permanently staying the proceedings (at least where the proceedings have been validly commenced and the summons gives sufficient particulars of the offence for the defendant to know the case that is put against it): Authorised Officer Ian Beer v D'Aquino [2006] NSWSC 996; BC200607675 at [8] [9] per Bell J.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 8] r 8 Copies of order

p.text: When the prosecutor files the summons, he shall lodge with the registrar two or more copies of a minute of the order which he claims.
[r 8 am Amendment 98: Gaz 142 of 19 October 1979 p 5275 ; Amendment 152: Gaz 103 of 29 June 1984 p 3411]

The summons and any affidavit in support of an application under section 246 of the subject Act shall not, unless the Court so directs, be served before the making of the order but shall be served on the defendant when the minute of order is served on him.
[subr (1) am Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]

Subject to any Act, a minute of any order made under section 246(1) or section 250(b) of the subject Act and any affidavits used to obtain either of those orders shall be served personally upon the defendant.
[subr (2) am Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.9.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 s 246, s 246(5)(b).
Section 246(5)(b) of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 permits an order to be made for the arrest of a person who fails in response to an order made under s 246 of the Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 10] r 10 Evidence of service

p.text: Evidence of service of any document in any proceedings to which this Division applies may be given by affidavit.

Where the Court, by subpoena or otherwise, orders any person to produce any document or thing, and any person makes and substantiates sufficient lawful objection to production on grounds of privilege, the Court shall not compel production of that document or thing except production to the Court for the purpose of ruling on the objection.

Where a question is put to a person in the course of examination, and any person makes and substantiates sufficient lawful objection on grounds of privilege to the question being answered, the Court shall not compel an answer to the question.

Subrule (1) applies where an order is made for production to, and subrule (2) applies where a question is put to a person in the course of examination before, the Court or a Judge or any officer of the Court, or any examiner, referee, arbitrator or other person authorised to receive evidence, whether on a trial or hearing or on any other occasion.
Where a party to any proceedings claims privilege from production of any document, the Court may, if it thinks fit:
permit evidence in relation to the claim to be given by any other party by affidavit or otherwise; and
permit cross-examination on any affidavit used in support of the claim.

This rule does not affect any rule of law which authorises or requires the withholding of any document or thing or the refusal to answer any question on the ground that the disclosure of the document or thing or the answering of the question would be injurious to the public interest.
Subrules (1), (2) and (3) do not apply to an objection to produce any document or thing or to answer any question on the ground mentioned in subrule (4).
[r 10A insrt Amendment 332: Gaz 98 of 27 August 1999 p 7460]
The insertion of r 10A by Amendment 332 commenced on 1 October 1999 and does not apply to a document that has been produced prior to that date.
The procedures prescribed by this rule shall be completed before the trial of a case commences.
This rule does not apply where the person charged with an offence pleads guilty to the offence or where the Judge dismisses the charge under section 249(1) or 251 of the subject Act.
[subr (2) am Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]
In this rule, trial includes the hearing and determination of the case and the adjudication on the case under section 250(a) of the subject Act.
[subr (3) am Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]
The Judge may, of his own motion or on the application of a party:
make orders and give directions for the just and efficient disposal of the proceedings;
without limiting the generality of paragraph (a) , make such orders and give such directions as may be appropriate relating to:
the giving by the plaintiff to the defendant of particulars or further and better particulars;

the giving by the plaintiff to the defendant of a list of persons who it is expected will be called to give evidence at the trial or, if the Judge thinks fit, who have made statements in writing but who it is expected will not be so called;

the giving by the plaintiff to the defendant of a copy of any statement made in writing by any person whose evidence it is expected will be given at the trial or, if that person has not made a statement in writing or if the Judge thinks fit, of a summary of the evidence which it is expected he will give at the trial;
the giving by the plaintiff to the defendant of a list of documents or things which it is expected will be tendered in evidence at the trial;
the giving by the plaintiff to the defendant of copies of documents;
inspection by the defendant of documents or of property;
any admission or consent of the defendant under section 184 of the Evidence Act 1995; and
any alibi.
[subr (4) Amendment 294: Gaz 102 of 25 August 1995 p 5015 ; am Amendment 332: Gaz 98 of 27 August 1999 p 7460 ; Amendment 338: Gaz 29 of 25 February 2000 p 1427]
The procedures prescribed by this rule are completed when the Judge certifies that in his opinion the pre-trial procedures prescribed by this rule have been completed.
[r 11 subst Amendment 98: Gaz 142 of 19 October 1979 p 5276]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.11.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 ss 249, Section 250, 251.

Criminal Procedure Act 1986 ss 249 and 251 permit the dismissal of proceedings where either the prosecutor does not appear, or where neither party appears, on an appointed hearing date. Section 250 of the Act relates to procedure when the person ordered to appear fails to attend, and permits the court either to proceed in the person’s absence, or adjourn the proceedings and make orders for the person’s apprehension.

Although the court has power to stay criminal proceedings in order to prevent an abuse of process or a denial of fairness to an accused, once a matter falls properly under the provisions of the subject Act the procedure which is prima facie appropriate for such matter is that provided by the Act and these Rules: Attorney-General (NSW) v Miller [1981] ACLD 465 at 558; see also Barton v R (1980) 147 CLR 75; 32 ALR 449 ; Miller v Ryan [1980] 1 NSWLR 93 . Contrast the procedure, relative to particulars, where committal proceedings take place: Moss v Brown [1979] 1 NSWLR 114.

For a discussion of pre-trial procedures in criminal proceedings, see G B Elkington, "Discovery upon Indictment in NSW" [1980] 4 Crim LJ 4. The drafting and enforcement of subpoenas in corporate criminal proceedings were considered in R v Barton [1981] 2 NSWLR 414 .
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.11.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 184, s 69.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 r 11(4).

Evidence Act 1995 s 69 , referred to in r 11(4) , makes certain statements in business records admissible into evidence. Evidence Act 1995 s 184 permits an accused, upon legal advice, to make admissions or give consents.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.11.6] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 75 r 11.

Pt 75 r 11 does not permit the court to order interrogatories. In order to alter the usual criminal procedure under an accusatory system, Parliament must make a clear statement to that effect: NSW Food Authority v Nutricia Aust Pty Ltd (2008) 72 NSWLR 456; [2008] NSWCCA 252; BC200809818 at [42]–[44] (stated case to Court of Criminal Appeal in relation to the setting aside of notices to provide information and/or documents). The failure of Pt 75 to incorporate the specific provisions of the UCPR relating to interrogatories is deliberate and reflects the long established incidents of criminal procedure: NSW Food Authority v Nutricia Aust Pty Ltd (2008) 72 NSWLR 456; [2008] NSWCCA 252; BC200809818 at [42] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 11A] r 11A Procedure where defendant does not appear

leg:heading.title: Procedure where defendant does not appear

p.text: If a defendant charged with two or more offences, whether of a like or different nature, does not appear at the time and place appointed for the hearing of the charges by the orders relating thereto, the Judge, upon proof in the manner prescribed of the due service of the orders upon him a reasonable time before the time appointed for his appearance, may proceed to hear and determine all or any of the charges together and adjudicate thereon in the absence of the defendant.
[r 11A insrt Amendment 152: Gaz 103 of 29 June 1984 p 3411]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 11B] r 11B Defendant to plead

p.text: Where the defendant appears at the hearing and has been provided with a written copy of the charges against him, the substance of the order under section 246(1) of the subject Act shall be stated to him, and he shall be asked if he has any cause to show why he should not be convicted or why an order should not be made against him.
[subr (1) am Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]

If he thereupon admits the truth of the charges and shows no sufficient cause why he should not be convicted or why an order should not be made against him, the Judge shall convict him or make an order against him accordingly.

If he does not admit the truth of the charges, the Judge shall proceed to hear the prosecutor and the witnesses whom he examines and such other evidence as he adduces in support of the charges and to hear the defendant and the witnesses whom he examines and such other evidence as he adduces in his defence.
[r 11B insrt Amendment 152: Gaz 103 of 29 June 1984 p 3411]
[r 12 rep Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 13] r 13 Termination of proceedings in a court of petty sessions

leg:heading.title: Termination of proceedings in a court of petty sessions

p.text: A Local Court is notified under section 255 of the subject Act of the commencement of proceedings under the subject Act for an offence when a minute of the order made under section 246 of the subject Act is delivered to a Magistrate or an authorised officer within the meaning of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 at the Local Court before which the proceedings for that offence are pending.
[subr (1) am Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]

A notice stating that the proceedings in the Local Court for the offence charged in the order have been terminated shall be served on the defendant with the minute of order under section 246 of the subject Act.
[subr (2) am Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8935, effective 29 August 2003]
[r 13 subst Amendment 98: Gaz 142 of 19 October 1979 p 5276]
[Note: Rules 14–19 rep by Amendment 98: Gaz 142 of 19 October 1979 p 5276]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.13.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 Pt 5, Section 255.
Section 255 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 provides for the determination of lower court proceedings when proceedings are commenced in the court under Pt 5 of Ch 4 of the Act.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 75.13.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 s 246.
Section 246 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 provides for Supreme Court orders for the attendance of an accused (on notice or by arrest) before the court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 75 r 14] r 14 Arrest warrants (cf former Part 42, rule 7)

p.text: Subject to rules of court:
if, by subpoena or otherwise, the Court makes an order, whether under an Act or under rules of court:
for a person to attend the Court for any purpose, or
for a person to produce any document or thing to the Court, and
the person fails to comply with the order,
the Court may issue, or make an order for the issue of, a warrant for the person’s arrest.
Subject to rules of court, an arrest warrant may be issued without notice to the person.
The Court may revoke an arrest warrant.

An arrest warrant is sufficient authority for any person to whom it is addressed, with the assistance of such police officers as may be necessary, to arrest the person named in the warrant, to convey the person to the place specified in the warrant and to deliver the person into the custody of the Court sitting at that place.
[r 14 insrt Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [94], effective 15 August 2005]
